qas.question: What monastic order did Bernard of Clairvaux belong to?
When did Bernard of Clairvaux die?
Along with Bari, what was a notable new pilgrimage site in this era?
Along with Rome and Jerusalem, what traditional pilgrimage site saw a greater number of visitors in the High Middle Ages?
Along with the Cistercians, what new monastic order was founded in the High Middle Ages?

context: The High Middle Ages was a period of great religious movements. Besides the Crusades and monastic reforms, people sought to participate in new forms of religious life. New monastic orders were founded, including the <a4_0>Carthusians<a4_0/> and the <a0_0>Cistercians<a0_0/>. The latter especially expanded rapidly in their early years under the guidance of Bernard of Clairvaux (d. <a1_0>1153<a1_0/>). These new orders were formed in response to the feeling of the laity that Benedictine monasticism no longer met the needs of the laymen, who along with those wishing to enter the religious life wanted a return to the simpler hermetical monasticism of early Christianity, or to live an Apostolic life. Religious pilgrimages were also encouraged. Old pilgrimage sites such as Rome, Jerusalem, and <a3_0>Compostela<a3_0/> received increasing numbers of visitors, and new sites such as <a2_0>Monte Gargano<a2_0/> and Bari rose to prominence.
